title: Fahour is Latitude's $51m man for the right moment
text:
But a successful float will also trigger a big payday for Fahour, who can receive a bonus of shares worth up to $22.5 million upon completion of the deal. That’s on top of a salary package which could be worth up to $4.8 million a year.

These are big numbers, to be sure. But there’s argument to be made that Fahour is exactly the right sort of chief executive to take Latitude, which was formerly part of global conglomerate GE, from private to public.

In many ways, this is the story of a company shifting from a background player – providing white-label solutions to run other people’s brands – to a true consumer business, with recognisable brands and a strong, visible presence in the Australian financial services market.

No matter what you think of Fahour, he is a leader with the personality and experience to front the show.

Note that the prospectus doesn’t include any pictures of Latitude’s former pitchman, Hollywood star Alec Baldwin – Fahour’s own star power will need to help carry this deal.

Selling points

There are three key points that Fahour and his advisers will be looking to sell ahead of the float, scheduled for October 23.

The first is that Latitude is perfectly placed to fill the gaps created by the banking sector’s deliberate or forced retreat from key sectors, particularly consumer lending.

Advertisement

In the 12 months since Fahour arrived, the big banks have reduced consumer lending by about 30 per cent; Latitude’s market share in this sector has risen from 9 per cent to 13 per cent, making it number three in this market, behind Commonwealth Bank and Westpac, but ahead of NAB and ANZ.

The second key point is that Latitude can provide investors with exposure to old-school, profitable consumer finance – cash profit is tipped at $287.6 million in the year to June 30 2020, up from $248.4 million in the 2018 financial year, before Fahour arrived – overlaid with exposure to booming technology-driven sectors such as smaller scale buy now, pay later transactions.

True, Latitude’s business in this end of the buy now, pay later sector is small, but the surging share prices of Afterpay, Zip and Flexigroup underline the consumer shift towards these types of payment models.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly, this is a float backed by private equity giant KKR, and the prospectus suggests there’s more than a bit of growth left in the tank.

It’s really not that long since Latitude was fully extracted from GE. What the company called its Latitude 2.0 strategy is still quite young.

In the past 12 months, Fahour has rebranded his credit card business and pushed into that smaller end of the buy now, pay later sector through the acquisition of New Zealand business, Genoapay. But the company’s board has just approved a five-year plan that will see Fahour push on with building up these new areas, and rebranding products across his portfolio..

The Latitude camp reckons its share of its addressable market across Australia and New Zealand is somewhere around 2 per cent. The argument is that if Fahour can get to 4 per cent in the coming years, profit should more than double, given improved operating leverage.

There are risks to this, of course. Getting consumer brands to resonate isn’t easy. While the banks are in retreat, the economy is fragile. And recent floats haven’t exactly set the world on fire.

As always with Ahmed, this will be fascinating to watch.
description: Ahmed Fahour stands to win big from Latitude's float, but he's also arguably the right man to steer this business from the shadows onto centre stage.
